key_points: UK Club, the insurer for the Ever Given, deems the reduced $600 million compensation claim by the Suez Canal Authority (SCA) as still 'exceptionally large'.
The SCA reduced its initial claim from $916 million in an attempt to settle the dispute out of court.
The Ever Given blocked the Suez Canal for six days in March, disrupting global maritime traffic.
The container ship is being held in a lake between two stretches of the canal amid a compensation dispute.
Osama Rabie, head of the SCA, sees no immediate prospect of settlement between the SCA and the ship's Japanese owner, Shoei Kisen.
UK Club claims the Ever Given's owners have not received evidence supporting the size of the compensation claim.
An Egyptian economic court is scheduled to hold a hearing on May 22 regarding the SCA's claim.
An Egyptian investigation found no wrongdoing by the SCA or its pilots.
The court might authorize the SCA to auction off the Ever Given if compensation is refused.
An Egyptian court has already rejected Shoei Kisen's appeal against the ship's detention.
